newsitem.title: USA: Salomon Bros April sales index up 3.6 percent.
newsitem.headline: Salomon Bros April sales index up 3.6 percent.

text.p: The Salomon Brothers same-store sales growth index rose 3.6 percent in April, which compared with a 1.3 percent rise a year ago, Salomon analysts said in a report.
The April index gain, however, was down compared with the 4.4 percent rise in March.

"April sales benefited from the timing of the Easter holiday, which resulted in one extra Sunday of sales versus last year, partially offset by unseasonably cool and wet weather in parts of the country," Salomon analysts said.
Because of the shift in Easter, with the holiday falling in March in 1997 and April in 1996, it is important to view sales results for the two months together, Salomon analysts said.
"Regardless, while there was some divergence by sector in April, on balance we believe that apparel retailers' results were somewhat weak due to the...poor weather," they added.

Despite the recent strength in stock prices for the group, Salomon analysts said they believe that strong inventory and expense controls will lead to retailers' earnings outpacing the average earnings of the S&P 500 beginning in the second quarter or the third quarter at the latest.
This will provide opportunities in select growth- and value-oriented retail equities, given their favorable risk/reward ratios, the analysts added.
